questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with complaints of fatigue, nausea, and right upper quadrant discomfort. O/E, she appears mildly jaundiced with yellowing of the sclera. She is drowsy but can be easily aroused. Her family reports that she has been more irritable than usual, displaying some behavioural changes. She denies any recent travel or known infections but admits to consuming alcohol excessively over the past month. Which of the following signs or symptoms is most characteristic of the severity of her condition?
questions.explanation:
Cause

Description

Viral hepatitis

Infections (A, B, E) that target the liver, causing inflammation and damage.

Alcoholic liver disease

Resulting from excessive alcohol consumption, it can present acutely with jaundice due to hepatitis.

Autoimmune hepatitis

The immune system attacks liver cells, presenting acutely with jaundice.

Drugs

Medications (e.g., paracetamol, halothane) and herbal remedies can lead to acute liver injury.

Poisons

Mushroom poisoning (Amanita phalloides) is a known cause of acute liver failure.

Other causes

Includes Wilson's disease, acute fatty liver of pregnancy, Budd–Chiari syndrome, and more.

Severity

Symptoms

Mild/Moderate Acute Liver Injury
  • Abnormal liver function tests (LFTs) (Option B ruled out)
  • Non-specific symptoms (e.g., fatigue), many asymptomatic.

Severe Acute Liver Injury
  • Jaundice: Yellowing of skin and eyes.
  • Signs of acute liver failure: Rapid decline in liver function, potential hepatic encephalopathy.
  • Cerebral disturbances: Often subtle and episodic in early stages.
  • Early signs of encephalopathy: Reduced alertness, poor concentration, behavioural abnormalities.
  • Progression of encephalopathy: Drowsiness, coma, cerebral oedema (unequal pupils, bradycardia, hyperventilation).

General Symptoms
  • Weakness
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Right hypochondrial discomfort

Finding

Description

Jaundice

May not be present initially.

Fetor hepaticus

A sweet, musty odour to the breath.

Liver Size

Usually normal or smaller; hepatomegaly is unusual.

Splenomegaly

Uncommon and never prominent.

Ascites and Oedema

Late developments, often a consequence of fluid therapy.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with alcoholic cirrhosis presents to the emergency department with confusion, disorientation, and asterixis. His family reports increasing drowsiness and difficulty concentrating over the past few days. Investigations reveal normal electrolytes and elevated ammonia levels. What is the most appropriate initial treatment to lower ammonia?
questions.explanation:
Hepatic Encephalopathy

Etiopathogenesis
  • It is a complication of chronic liver disease that leads to impaired brain function as a result of liver failure.
  • It is also called as portosystemic encephalopathy.
  • Ammonia is a gut-derived neurotoxin that is not detoxified into urea and bypasses the liver due to portosystemic shunting and decreased hepatic mass, allowing it to enter the bloodstream and impact the brain.


 

Types

Type A is caused by acute liver failure & cerebral oedema is a common side effect of this type.

Type B is caused by portosystemic shunting (can be due to TIPS also)

Type C is due to chronic liver failure.













 

Clinical manifestations

Grade 0 - alterations are seen in neuropsychological tests, but only minimal symptomatic changes are evident in

  • Short-term memory,
  • Reaction time or
  • Concentration.

Grade 1:

  • Mood changes like anxiety, euphoria;
  • Memory trouble,
  • Trivial lack of awareness,
  • Difficulty with addition and subtraction,
  • Impaired sleep pattern.

Grade 2:

  • Personality changes
  • Lethargy & apathy
  • Behavior changes
  • Dysarthria
  • Disorientation for time

Grade 3:

  • Severe confusion, delirium
  • Disorientation to place
  • Drowsiness
  • Bizarre behavior
  • Asterixis

Grade 4: Coma (total loss of consciousness)

Grade 0,1 are considered convert or minimal hepatic encephalopathy, and grades 2,3,4 are overt hepatic encephalopathy with evident symptoms.

Investigations
  • Psychometric tests
  • Complete clinical evaluation
  • Blood investigations like LFT
  • Doppler ultrasound to evaluate the liver
  • EEG & MRI to assess brain activity

Management
  • Lactulose
  • Rifaximin (Option C) reduces ammonia production; it is an adjunctive therapy in patients who do not tolerate lactulose.
  • Neomycin is an alternative to Rifaximin.
  • Branched-chain amino acids and probiotics
  • Zinc supplementation, used as adjunct therapy (Option B)
  • Restricted protein intake was used in the past but is not commonly used due to its risk of malnutrition outweighs the benefits (Option A)
  • IV hydration is a vital supportive measure

Investigation of choice to measure pressure gradient.

It also shows leukopenia and anaemia.

(Option A ruled out)

CT and MRI Scan (Option A ruled out)

Assess the extent of portal vein thrombosis and evaluate hepatic vein patency.

HVPG Measurement

It is rarely performed by interventional radiology to measure hepatic venous pressure gradient directly.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with jaundice, pruritus, and fatigue. He reports experiencing night sweats, fever, and unintentional weight loss over the past month. Laboratory tests reveal elevated alkaline phosphatase and bilirubin levels. A liver biopsy shows loss of intrahepatic bile ducts. Further evaluation shows enlarged lymph nodes in the cervical region. What is the most likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Paraneoplastic Findings in Classical Hodgkin Lymphoma (cHL)
  • Rare paraneoplastic syndromes have been observed at the time of cHL diagnosis.
  • Syndromes include:
    • Vanishing bile duct syndrome (Option B) and idiopathic cholangitis with clinical jaundice.
    • Nephrotic syndrome (membranous glomerulopathy) with anasarca.
    • Autoimmune hematologic disorders such as immune thrombocytopenia or hemolytic anaemia.
    • Various neurologic signs and symptoms.
  • While direct CNS or meningeal involvement in cHL is rare, neurological paraneoplastic syndromes include:
    • Subacute cerebellar degeneration.
    • Myelopathy.
    • Progressive multifocal encephalopathy.
    • Limbic encephalitis.
  • Hypercalcemia

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with severe back pain and weakness in her legs. She has been experiencing fatigue and increased thirst for the past month. Laboratory tests reveal: Serum calcium : 13 mg/dL Serum creatinine : 150 μmol/L (1.7 mg/dL) Hemoglobin : 8.5 g/dL Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) : 70 U/L (normal range) Serum phosphate : 3.5 mg/dL (normal) Imaging reveals findings as shown:  Based on this clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Diagnostic Criteria for Multiple Myeloma (Option C)

Presence of clonal bone marrow plasma cells or biopsy-proven bony/extramedullary plasmacytoma and anyone or more of the following myeloma-defining events:

Evidence of one or more indicators of end-organ damage attributed to the plasma cell disorder, specifically: (CRAB)

  • Hypercalcemia: Serum calcium >0.25 mmol/L above the upper limit of normal or >2.75 mmol/L (>11 mg/dL).
  • Renal Insufficiency: Creatinine clearance <40 mL/min or serum creatinine >177 μmol/L (>2 mg/dL).
  • Anemia: Hemoglobin >20 g/L below the lower limit of normal or haemoglobin <100 g/L or <10g/100ml.
  • Bone Lesions: One or more osteolytic lesions identified on skeletal radiography, CT, or PET-CT.

Biomarkers of Malignancy (any one of the following):

  • Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥60%.
  • Involved: uninvolved serum-free light chain ratio ≥100.
  • 1 focal lesion on MRI studies.
